She has worked with 'comfort women' survivors across Asia for over a decade, supporting their advocacy including the Women's International War Crimes Tribunal for Japan's Military Sexual Slavery. As Project Coordinator for Women's Caucus for Gender Justice, she lobbed the UN to incorporate gender into the International Criminal Court, and coordinated a documentary film production featuring this global women's movement. She co-built Women In Black Tokyo after 911 and staged street performances to end violence and militarism through the neo-con era.    She is a co-founder, producer and exhibiting artist of Renren-Yawa Vgirls, a group of women artists in their 20s-40s presenting/creating space for feminist art in Tokyo. She co-produced, scripted and acted in a series of productions in Tokyo, where she organized women to develop consciousness over gender issues confronting their lives and perform their stories in public. As part of Feminist Active Documentary Video Festa, she co-documented visits to tsunami survivors and screened it for survivors and people in other areas of Japan to mediate relationships in between and to engage women in the reconstruction process. In 2013, Miho and other members of the Tokyo-based artist collective Stand Up Sisters exhibited the "One Thousand Needles Project", a thousand stitch belt, or "sennibari", to enourage war memory and promote peace, at the Hako Gallery in Yoygi Uehara.    Miho's art emerges out of her personal encounters/relationships with people living to overcome injustice, oppression or difficult social conditions. Her visual art, poetry, photography, film and performance works address and respond to human conditions, and is embedded in the lives of people mediating empowerment, relationship building and transpiration of life with dignity.    She has written and spoken extensively on her works. She is also a professional translator/interpreter. She was born in Osaka and grew up in Europe. She holds a BA from Swarthmore College, U.S., and studied Figurative Art at Bigakko, Japan.  Ralph Castaldo 2013 Art & Public Policy       Web Site:        www.castaldodesigngroup.org Ralph A. Castaldo returned to NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts twenty-two years after receiving his MFA in Scenic Design from the Department of Design for Stage and Film, and 27 years after completing a BA in Politics/Pre-Law from NYU’s Washington Square and University College. He designs for professional and academic theatre and for events worldwide, from New York to San Francisco to Shenzhen, China. His designs for commencement exercises at Radio City Music Hall are regularly published in the Rose Brand catalog. Ralph also designs for film, most notably working with Nitin Desai and the National Film Development Corporation of India on their 2000 feature, Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar, which won three National Film Awards in India. Repeatedly, he has seen the worlds of Art and Politics come together; sometimes peacefully, and sometimes colliding. As a professor of theatre arts, he is constantly reminded that the best way to ensure that the Arts thrive is through education, and he has stepped back into the classroom – now as a student – to make this a reality in his own life. Ralph’s dedication to education is also seen in his alumni work and his continual placement of new graduates in his many projects. With the Department of Design for Stage and Film, he is a founding member and presently Chair of Tisch Design Alumni. He also sits on the Board of the New York University Alumni Association. Ralph will continue designing and teaching, and has plans to launch an Italian-American theatre company in New York City. He lives with his wife, Laurie, in Pelham, NY... sharing their house with Oliver and Lucia, their two amazingly wonderful dogs. It doesn’t get much better than this. Ricardo Gamboa 2013 Art & Public Policy Ricardo Gamboa is a artist, activist, and academic. He graduated from the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign in 2003 (B.A. Spanish) and then began his career in his native Chicago. There he was the Artistic Director of Teatro Americano, company member of Barrel of Monkeys, and worked with young people throughout the city using performance and media as a means for empowerment. In 2010 he moved to New York City where he has since participated in the Hemispheric Institute of Performance and Politics EmergeNYC program, made socially conscious youth media at Scenarios USA, and became a NY Neo-Futurist. Gamboa received his M.A. in Arts Politics from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts and is pursuing his doctorate degree in American Studies in the university's school of Social and Cultural Analysis. He has received several awards for his performance and writing work and in May 2013 his first feature film Maydays premiered at the Chicago Latino Film Festival. Gamboa's work during 2013-2014 includes artist residencies with National Museum of Mexican Art and Free Street Theater, creating a series of performance art short film exploring the experiences of Chicago's Mexican-American and queer communities, and filming his second feature film.  Ellen McTigue 2013 Art & Public Policy Ellen McTigue has sung, danced, and performed since the age of 5. She received a B.A. from Columbia College in Chicago in Arts Management, and most recently earned her M.A. from New York University's Tisch School of the Arts. While living and studying in New York, Ellen's main area of interest was learning how to use the stage a platform for growth. Her professional and personal vision is to use the theatre for bringing art and its educational and inspirational powers to those most in need of acceptance -- most specifically the differently abled community and women struggling with self acceptance and body image issues. "There is a strong and desperate need to rework the definition of disability. It's not just black and white anymore. We need to give it a space, an art form, and a sage on which to present it with a powerful and loud voice. It's no longer about creating art to simply delight the senses."    Now, Ellen is living and working in Los Angeles, California. She continues to work on her body image performance art piece (inspired by the likes of Eve Ensler, Marina Abramovic and David Wojnarowicz) currently entitled "Exhibiting Misogyny: the story of a _______ girl" along with exploring her photography skills in a piece that she hopes will coincide with her performance.  Tyler S. Bugg 2013 Art & Public Policy Tyler S. Bugg is a writer, activist, and arts-based organizer working within the intersections of theatre and dance, memory, and trauma. He aims to facilitate the creation of new stage plays and performance art works that serve as sites of reconciliation for the communities their themes engage.    Originally from Augusta, Georgia, Tyler was a student of international affairs and cultural geography at the University of Georgia. During his time there, he developed extensive public advocacy and organizing experience, serving as a senior intern with the Office of Congressman John Barrow, an operations coordinator with Teach For America, a regional organizer for STAND: the student-led division of United to End Genocide, an organizing fellow with Obama for America, and as associate editor for the Georgia Political Review. His writing has appeared in Racialicious, PolicyMic, Next New Deal, The Nation, and several other policy journals and collective community anthologies. In April 2012, he was named a Millennial Values Fellow with Georgetown University's Berkley Center for Religion, Peace, and World Affairs. Graduating summa cum laude in 2012 with a Bachelor of Arts in Comparative Politics, Tyler was also awarded the university’s Pearson Atlas Prize.    In addition to his advocacy work, Tyler has also both acted in and directed several community-based plays, including El Teatro Campesino’s Los Vendidos, Eve Ensler’s A Memory, A Monologue, A Rant, and A Prayer, and the self-written He Said, She Said, Zhe Said: Gender Stories; an original dance installation, I break and I build; and his solo performance series, Paternalism in the living room of small town America. Megan Rollins 2012 Art & Public Policy Things had been downhill for Megan after she peaked at the age of 9, appearing as Michelle Tanner's "friend" in an episode of the TV series Full House. But, in the summer of 2006, with the help of an inordinate amount of Venti Starbucks Coffees and dumpster-chic clothing, Megan was revived and joined the Los Angeles staff of the Huffington Post. In 2007, when Barack Obama announced his candidacy for President, Megan took a position with Evolutionary Media Group to work on the grassroots visibility campaign. Ava Ansari 2011 Art & Public Policy Ava Ansari is an artist and curator graduated from the Arts-Politics MA program in May 2011. As an artist, Ava finds the most value when she succeed in creating collective moments of collaboration, education, and creation. She plays on this directly in Subway, an interactive artwork in progress, that includes a video, a freely available Android app, and hundreds of still images collected from participants in Iran—Subway tests the subversive possibilities of digital media. A collaboration with Andrew Quitmeyer and the Digital World and Image Group which has been accepted and presented in different venues including ISEA, ArtsIT, and Artaud.    Ava sees the voluntary collaborative attitude toward making art as vitally important, urgent, and a way of interrelating that can expand from the art community into the society at large. This belief in the power of collective art practice and the need for safe spaces for experimentation and collaborative art making led her to co-found the Back Room, a liquid curatorial and pedagogical platform in 2011. The Back Room’s mission is to use new media to facilitate exchanges between artists, curators, and scholars, in the US and Iran, circumventing the boundaries and limitations of transporting works, travel cost, and the bureaucracy of getting a visa. Though the project started between Tehran and NYC, it has now expanded to three other major cities in Iran.    Ava currently works at Aperture. She has previously worked in curatorial positions at Basement Gallery, Dubai, and Silk Road Gallery, Tehran and as an artist has presented work at Dixon Place, La Mama, Eyebeam, the AC Institute, among other. During her tenure, GFS received the Mayor's Award for Art and Culture, was recognized by Russell Simmons at his Art For Life Benefit and spear headed its first Annual Benefit Dinner. Recently, GFS opened the Cinema School, the first high school in the nation with a focus on filmmaking. She is currently producing, THE GANG OF FOUR, a documentary revealing the extraordinary 50 year political legacy of Percy Sutton, Basil Paterson, David Dinkins and Charles Rangel, collectively known as the Gang of Four and AUTISTIC LIKE ME, the personal journey of five African American fathers of son’s with autism. As the Managing Partner of Femme Noir Films, Ms. Thomas is committed to telling stories with dynamic female leads. She is a full member of BAFTA and a Tribeca Film Festival Industry Delegate and was recently named as one of the Top Ten Rising Women Executives in Entertainment by Uptown Magazine.  Ayesha Omer 2011 Art & Public Policy Ayesha Omer is an artist and educator based in Karachi, Pakistan. Her work addresses issues of public formation, social marginalization and art activism. She trained in Arts Politics at the Tisch School of Art, NYU, after receiving a degree in Political Science from Davidson College, N.C. She teaches Cultural Studies and Arts Politics at the Indus Valley School of Art and Architecture in Karachi, Pakistan.    Her art practice is collaborative and cross-cultural. Currently, she is working with artist Fahad Naveed Zahidi on “Love Letters to Karachi” (2012 – present): a community-based letter-writing project with different communities of Karachi.    "Where’s My Revolution?" (2011 – present) is a response to social movements in Pakistan and around the world that aims to facilitate collaborative, cross-cultural art projects that build solidarity among activists and artists. “Mukhatib Awaam" (2013 – present) is social media public campaign in collaboration with Rahnuma Design Matters to respond to Pakistan’s issues of religious intolerance, class divides, gender discrimination and environmental degradation.       Photo Credit: Bartek Górka, courtesy of CCA Ujazdowski Castle, Warsaw top Roslyn Helper 2011 Art & Public Policy       Web Site:        http://roslynhelper.tumblr.com/ Roslyn is the Artistic Co-Director of Electrofringe, an organization dedicated to nurturing and presenting experimental technology-based art through an annual program of interactive exhibitions, workshops and performances. Roslyn is also Co-Founder and Co-Director of zin, a Sydney-based live art partnership that creates audience-driven, socially engaged works focusing on the power of experience by combining immersive, visceral and hybrid-art elements. Roslyn completed a BA (Media and Communications) from Sydney University in 2010 and an MA in Arts Politics from Tisch School of the Arts in 2011. She is most interested in contemporary artforms and modes of participation that investigate and reorient our positions within social, political and economic systems.    Electrofringe - http://electrofringe.net/ and http://vimeo.com/85495737    zin - http://zinari.org/  Lauren Nicole Nixon 2010 Art & Public Policy       Web Site:        www.laurennicolenixon.com Lauren Nixon is a food and sustainability educator. During her undergraduate work at The New School, her background in Dance Studies , a field that recognizes movement and the physical body as catalysts for comprehending both history and culture, provided a framework for her interest in holistic health, a field that encourages individuals to listen to their physical bodies in order to achieve optimal health and wellness. Nixon’s studies at New York University in Arts Politics acted as a catalyst for her interest in social justice in relation to food, sustainability and the environment.    Lauren uses her academic and professional experiences in education, administration, research, feminist studies, queer theory, and Black studies to inform her work with food and holistic health. Her experiences include FoodCorps, Hidden Villa, Sing for Hope, Brooklyn Museum, The I Have a Dream Foundation, Smithsonian’s Discovery Theatre, Pentacle, Creative Action, Smithsonian Institute, Imagination Stage and Round House Theatre.    Photo Credit: Adrianne Koteen  Marjuan Canady 2010 Art & Public Policy       Web Site:        www.marjuancanady.com                                        Marjuan Canady, a native Washingtonian with  Trinidadian/Black American roots, is a published writer, actress, playwright,  director, educator and producer for both film and the stage. Her one-woman  play, Girls! Girls? Girls. has been featured  Off-Broadway, at national festivals and regional theaters. Her second  play, Callaloo: A Jazz Folktale has been seen at the  Ellington Theater and IATI Theater. For this work, Canady served as a featured  playwright at the 2013 Lincoln Center for Performing Arts Director’s Lab.  A Matteo Ricci and Schomburg Mellon Fellow, Canady is the founder and creative  director of her production company, Sepia  Works . Her diverse acting  work includes plays, films, television, commercials and voiceovers. Canady  currently writes for The Caribbean Current and recently starred and co-produced  the short film The Resort shot in Tobago, WI.  She is also currently directing the documentary, Girls! Girls? Girls.  set to release in 2015. In 2013 she  published her first children’s book Callaloo: A Jazz  Folktale  which she was recognized by The National Library of Trinidad and Tobago  in their First Time Author’s Program.  She is a  graduate of Duke Ellington School of the Arts and holds a B.A. in  Theater/African Studies from Fordham University and her M.A. in Arts Politics  from New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts.  Wan-Jung Wei 2010 Art & Public Policy Wan-Jung Wei, a native of Taiwan, is an art administrator and dancer with extensive experience on both creative and administrative aspects of theatrical production. When working in Solar Art Management , one of the leading art management companies in Taiwan, Wei contributed in all phases of production including dance performance, set design and marketing. She has brought several world-known acts to Taiwan, including Maria Serrano Flamenco Dance Company and the Disney musical Winnie the Pooh , adding diversity to performance business. Besides working on theater productions, Wei is also one of the founding members of DX5, an award-winning contemporary dance company in Taiwan. She received her B.A in International Relations from National Taiwan University in 2005.  Noelle Ghoussaini 2010 Art & Public Policy       Web Site:        www.noelleghoussaini.com  Noelle Ghoussaini is  an American-Lebanese playwright, director and community artist. She creates  theatrical events dedicated to examining and re-imagining our society within a  political, social and historical context. She  has written and directed 5 original plays, the most recent, phoenicia  flowers, was produced by NOOR theatre in the Spring of 2014. In  2013, Noelle received the Create Change Fellowship with the Laudromat Project   and was a part of the Lincoln Center Directors's lab. She has written,  directed and choreographed with companies such as Culture Project, the Jenin  Freedom Theatre, New York Theatre Workshop, Sepia Works, Noor Theatre, the  Bolshoi Drama theatre, and the Movement Theatre Company. She  has also led workshops on community-based arts at UNESCO in Paris and the  Queens Museum in NYC. She  holds an M.A. in Arts Politics from NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts and a B.A.  in Performance Studies, French and African Studies from Northwestern  University.                                             top Clara Inés Schuhmacher 2010 Art & Public Policy       Web Site:        www.vvitalny.com                                    Born in Italy to Argentine parents, Clara Inés  Schuhmacher is an artist, writer and producer interested in participatory  public art and creative placemaking. She currently serves as Director of  Operations for Make Music New York, where she facilitates the creation of  thousands of free, participatory musical events across New York City annually  on June 21. She also serves as Associate Producer for the New York Village  Halloween Parade, the largest of its kind in the United States. From 2008-2013,  she was Development Manager for Institutional Giving for the American Music  Center, where she played a key role in supporting the organization through a  merger which resulted in New Music USA. Prior, she served as Assistant Artistic  Director of the new media festival Pixilierations, under the auspices of  Providence’s FirstWorks.      Clara is a founding artist member  of vvitalny, a collective that looks to time-based art to tell stories of love,  language and transnationality; their video art & installations have been  presented in the United States, Europe, Israel and Argentina. Her multimedia  journalism appears in Serious Eats, the Huffington Post and Organic Gardening.  She is the co-founder of Brown Opera Productions in Providence, RI, and as a  vocalist she has performed across Europe, Russia, South America and the United  States, most recently with the Tanglewood Festival Chorus. Clara holds a  BA in Ethnomusicology from Brown University, and an MA in Arts Politics from  NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts. She lives in Brooklyn, New York.      Esther Chang 2010 Art & Public Policy Esther is a Senior Producer and Strategic Consultant with experience leading and executing global interactive, experiential, digital productions, campaigns, and cause-based communications for brands, start-ups and international NGO's. Some projects include: managing the production of the first free skate park in India, creating multi-platform content with Deepak Chopra and luminaries (Nobel Laureate’s Leymah Gbowee and Wangari Maathai, actors Mark Ruffalo, Fran Drescher, Adrian Grenier, and Goldie Hawn, TED Prize winners JR and Karen Armstrong, Bobby Kennedy Jr, Arianna Huffington, Dylan Ratigan, Congressman Tim Ryan, Musician Donovan and rapper 50 Cent), producing art and music festivals (The Last Weekend, Pitchfork Music Festival, SXSW, Coachella) to fundraisers for President Barack Obama and Alicia Keys. Parallel to this journey is a deep passion and commitment to the fight against HIV/AIDS. 2014 marks a decade of volunteering as a counselor and mentor to youth living with the virus in the US and East Africa. She currently advises various international health organizations on program development, fundraising, marketing, and volunteer recruitment. She is also a certified Sivananda Yoga Teacher and Little Flower Yoga & Mindfulness Instructor for Children and Youth. Esther has a BA in Ethnic Studies from the University of California, Berkeley and an MA in Arts Politics from New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts.  Victoria Lynford 2010 Art & Public Policy Victoria "Tory" Lynford is an Arts Administrator trained on both sides of the proscenium in production and fundraising. With 12 years of experiences in the cultural area, she produces public programming centered on arts, communities and social consciousness. She has worked with many of NYC's vital arts institutions including BAM, Creative Capital, Central Park Summerstage and Creative Time. She has also managed emerging not-for-profit arts groups and believes that this difference in scale has given her a unique understanding of how to produce performing and visual art initiatives on budgets of all sizes.    Tory is the Executive Director of the New York City Arts Coalition, an advocacy based collective of approximately 250 arts organizations that promotes a broad awareness of the arts in the life of the city. It encourages leaders and elected officials to protect the creative freedom of the arts community and to support adequate appropriations for the arts in the city, state and federal budgets. Concurrently, she serves as Program Manager of American Photography Archives Group (APAG) where she works to preserve the archives of many of the 20th century's most iconic photographers.    Additionally, in support of the NYC arts community, Tory is active with the Steering Committee of the Brooklyn Museum's Sackler Center for Feminist Art, and is a member of the Board of Directors of Moving Theater, a not-for-profit dance theater company.    She earned a Bachelors degree in Literature and Theatre Arts from Hobart & William Smith Colleges, and is certified in Arts Administration from NYU School of Continuing Education and Professional Studies. Tory was a recipient of the New York Foundation For the Arts BUILD grant award, and a three-time grant awardee from Rockefeller Brothers Fund for her work with Moving Theater. She is a fifth generation New Yorker and resides in Downtown Brooklyn.  M. Liz Andrews 2009 Art & Public Policy       Web Site:        www.LetterToObama.com M. Liz Andrews (2009) is an artist, curator, educator and serves as an administrator in the Department of Photography & Imaging at Tisch. While in the Arts Politics program, Liz conceptualized the LetterToObama project: a platform for people to present letters to the President… in the form of art. She believes that art has a unique power to document histories, convey messages, envision change and incite action. She is particularly passionate about vocal music performance. M. Liz Andrews was born and raised in Denver, Colorado and currently resides in New York City.    M. Liz Andrews held her second LetterToObama in New York City on September 11, 2011 to commemorate the tenth anniversary of the twin towers. Liz also performed and composed the music and choreography for a production of blood pudding a jazz aesthetic theater in April. In fall 2012, Liz will enter the Ph.D. in Cultural Studies at George Mason University to continue her work on art and social change.  Olive McKeon 2009 Art & Public Policy Olive Mckeon is a doctoral student at the University of California, Los Angeles, writing a dissertation on historical materialism, feminism, and dance studies. She is involved in university organizing and feminist groups. After earning her BFA in Performance from Tisch in 2002, Jackie worked as a youth drama instructor for a variety of organizations across the greater NY area. Daniel Sander 2009 Art & Public Policy Daniel Sander is currently a doctoral student in the Department of Performance Studies, Tisch School of the Arts, New York University where his research interests include the philosophy of desire, the psychopathology of deviance, libidinal materialism, and queer nihilism.  Azza Satti 2009 Art & Public Policy       Web Site:        www.acuteobservation.com Azza Satti is a producer, educator and curator from Sudan. She has previously worked for Opening Act Theater, Rashid Diab Arts Centre and Japan Society, and holds a B.A. in Media Studies from Hunter College. She is on the board of Asmi international, a non-profit that trains young leaders in displaced populations to use theater and literacy to reclaim their identity, and she is leading the al-Mashish theater partnership in Nyala, Darfur.  Chelsea Whitaker 2009 Art & Public Policy       Web Site:        http://www.chelseawhitaker.com Chelsea is a multimedia artist who is exploring the intersection of new media and social causes though her work in online marketing. Anne Marie Butler 2009 Art & Public Policy       Web Site:        https://buffalo.academia.edu/AnneMarieButler Anne Marie Butler holds a B.A. from  Scripps College with a dual major in Art History and French, and an M.A. from  New York University in Arts Politics. Her career experience includes progressive policy research at the Brennan Center for Justice at NYU School of Law, community-oriented arts journalism at the Williamsburg Greenpoint News + Arts , and various performance pursuits on guitar and piano with her soul/funk band, with Seattle-based band Lawn-dree, as a classical violinist, and as music director for several Seattle-based original productions. RonAmber Deloney 2008 Art & Public Policy RonAmber Deloney graduated with BAs in English and German from Austin College. After her undergraduate studies she went to Berlin, Germany on a Fulbright scholarship where she did performance research on slam poetry and was a grassroots community organizer with local artists and activists. Some of the cool projects RonAmber achieved during this time include getting published, completing a spoken word album as The New Night Babies, working with The Last Poets to secure gigs around Europe and moderating discussions with Amiri Baraka and Jayne Cortez at The House of World Cultures. After 3.5 years in Berlin, she moved back to the US and attended Tisch where she found more direction for her activist interests. In 2011 she will graduate with an M.S.Ed in Adolescent Education from St Johns University, Manhattan campus. She has been writing instructional units at the intersection of arts and social justice. She plans to be a school resource instructor and teach an arts politics class in high schools. Her objective is to engage students in critical thinking and writing through creative curriculum.    The New Night Babies will also release a 2nd album, Lilac and Rapeseed, in the coming months. The New Night Babies is the effort of friends Khabo and two awesome brothers, Joerg and Frank Pokall who recorded both albums, Of Brickwalls and Breezeways and Lilac and Rapeseed, in Frank's bedroom in Berlin. It's electronic spoken word and Khabo's tracks on the first album are hip-hop influenced.
